page.title: 15ECOLOGY- CHANGING LAND COVER
page.content: Evidence for this work was given by{ {Mrs. Duncan}who is the secretary of the{Wharfedale Naturalists.} {Mrs. Duncan}says that on the top of the moorland the heather is returning, although it had disappeared when the{ {1959-1960}survey was done by the Wharfedale Naturalists. This was because the sheep were grazing uncontrolably and they eat the {heather.}Grazing is now being restricted so the{heather}is returning. Now there are many rocks covered in plants such as{crowberry {and bilberry.}In{1903}was much heather and little grazing of sheep. Now there are many wet areas on the moor where{horsetail cotton grass}and many{headed cotton grasses}grow. Grazing makes a large difference to the vegitation on the moor as sheep only eat certain types of vegitation.
